contentrichtext.text: {{for|the Irish Centre Party founded in 1919|Stephen Gwynn}} {{Infobox political party |country = the Republic of Ireland |name_english = National Centre Party |name_native = |logo = |leader = [[Frank MacDermot]] |chairman = |secretary_general = |leader1_title = |leader1_name = |foundation = 1932 |dissolution = 1933 |headquarters = |ideology = [[Christian democracy]],<br>[[Conservatism]],<br>[[Centrism]] |position = [[Centre-right]] |merged = [[Fine Gael]] |colorcode = {{National Centre Party (Ireland)/meta/color}} }} The '''National Centre Party''', initially known as the '''National Farmers and Ratepayers League''', was a short-lived political party in the [[Irish Free State]]. It was founded in December 1932 with the support of several sitting [[Teachta Dála|TD]]s, including the four [[Farmers' Party (Ireland)|Farmers' Party]] members and thirteen [[Independent (politics)|Independent]]s, all of whom feared for their political future if they did not coordinate in a common organisation. Prominent among the latter were party leader [[Frank MacDermot]], a TD for [[Roscommon (Dáil Éireann constituency)|Roscommon]] since the [[Irish general election, 1932|general election of February 1932]], and [[James Dillon (Fine Gael politician)|James Dillon]], a TD for [[Donegal (Dáil Éireann constituency)|Donegal]], who was the son of [[John Dillon]], the last leader of the [[Irish Parliamentary Party]]. The party's policies included the establishment of a central bank (at this time, the Free State was still part of the [[Pound sterling|sterling]] area, and the [[Bank of Ireland]] served as lender to the government), [[deflation]] through pay cuts, [[protectionism]], an end to the [[Anglo-Irish Trade War]] and the removal of [[Rates (tax)|rates]] on agricultural land. The party was strongly opposed to [[Fianna Fáil]], despite apparent similarities of policy, perhaps because most National Centre Party deputies represented rural constituencies. Fianna Fáil, with its strength among small farmers and increasing popularity among the rural middle-class, was the most obvious threat to a rural-based party at this time. In the [[Irish general election, 1933|general election of January 1933]], the new party won eleven seats. During this election, the party's opponents in Fianna Fáil disrupted National Centre Party meetings, often with the assistance of the prohibited [[Irish Republican Army]]. These incidents contributed to the rise of the [[Army Comrades Association]], which was formed to protect the establishment conservative parties from the perceived threat of political violence. Fianna Fáil formed a [[majority government]] after the election. During the first Fianna Fáil government, the National Centre Party aligned with the largest opposition party, [[Cumann na nGaedheal]], on almost all issues of political or economic importance. However, Frank MacDermot rejected a suggestion that the two parties should merge. The opposition parties united in mutual self-defence when the government banned the Army Comrades Association in August 1933. The two parties and the ACA merged to form [[Fine Gael]] in September, just eleven months after the formation of the National Centre Party. Although MacDermot became a Vice-President of Fine Gael at its foundation, he differed from most of his party colleagues on issues such as the degree of emphasis to be given to Ireland's membership of the [[Commonwealth of Nations|British Commonwealth]].
